message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia protrudes through the external inguinal ring, bypassing the inguinal canal, which is a characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia. An indirect inguinal hernia passes through the inguinal canal and into the scrotum. A femoral hernia protrudes through the femoral ring, and an incisional hernia occurs at a site of a previous incision. Isolated rectus diastasis refers to separation of the two rectus abdominis muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia sac protrudes through the external inguinal ring, which bypasses the inguinal canal. This is characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia. An indirect inguinal hernia goes through the inguinal canal, while a femoral hernia protrudes through the femoral canal. Incisional hernias occur at the site of a previous surgical incision, and rectus diastasis is a separation of the rectus abdominis muscles without a true hernia sac.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia sac bypassing the inguinal canal suggests a direct inguinal hernia. An indirect femoral hernia passes through the femoral canal, whereas a direct inguinal hernia passes through the external inguinal ring. A direct incisional hernia forms at a site of previous surgery, and isolated rectus diastasis is not a hernia, but a separation of the abdominal muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia protrudes through the external inguinal ring, indicating a direct inguinal hernia. Indirect femoral hernias protrude through the femoral canal, not the inguinal canal. Direct incisional hernias and isolated rectus diastasis do not involve the inguinal area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The protrusion through the external inguinal ring suggests a direct inguinal hernia. Indirect femoral hernias pass through the femoral canal, direct incisional hernias occur at the site of a previous incision, and isolated rectus diastasis is a separation of the rectus abdominis muscles with no herniation of intra-abdominal contents.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia sac passing through the external inguinal ring without entering the inguinal canal suggests a direct inguinal hernia. Indirect femoral hernia would pass through the femoral canal, not the inguinal ring. Direct incisional hernia would occur at a previous surgical incision site. Isolated rectus diastasis is a separation of the rectus abdominus muscle, not a hernia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia sac protruding through the external inguinal ring bypassing the inguinal canal suggests a direct inguinal hernia. An indirect femoral hernia would protrude through the femoral canal, and a direct incisional hernia occurs through a previous surgical incision. Rectus diastasis does not involve a hernia sac protruding through a ring or canal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hernia sac protrudes through the external inguinal ring, which bypasses the inguinal canal, suggesting a direct inguinal hernia. Indirect femoral hernia protrudes through the femoral canal, not the inguinal canal. Direct incisional hernia occurs at the site of a previous surgical incision, and isolated rectus diastasis is a separation of the rectus abdominis muscles without a hernia sac.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this case, the hernia sac bypasses the inguinal canal, which is characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia. Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the internal inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, while femoral hernias pass through the femoral canal below the inguinal ligament. Incisional hernias occur at a site of previous surgical incision and involve weakness in the abdominal wall. Rectus diastasis is a separation of the rectus abdominis muscles, but does not involve a hernia sac protruding through a weakness in the abdominal wall.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the hernia protruding through the external inguinal ring and bypassing the inguinal canal is characteristic of a direct inguinal hernia. An indirect femoral hernia would protrude through the femoral canal instead of the inguinal canal, while a direct incisional hernia would occur at the site of a previous surgical incision. Isolated rectus diastasis refers to separation of the rectus muscles without an actual hernia.
